msgSnippet: ... I m not sure why you think that being forced to have a method name start with test is OOP? 2)  What I m not prepared to accept, is an assertion that ...
messageBody:
On 9/16/06, Marvin Toll <MarvinToll@...> wrote:
>
>
> 1) There are contexts where both an OOP solution and a declarative
> solution is effective. I happen to prefer an OOP solution as a
> first choice. ("test" vs "@Test")


I'm not sure why you think that being forced to have a method name start
with "test" is OOP?


2) What I'm not prepared to accept, is an assertion that
> declarative programming is "better" (when there are two workable
> choices) by virtue of its existence.


It is better in this case, because munging your method names so that a tool
can pick them off is clearly better addressed with annotations.

In the case of @Ignore - no
> question about it (in my mind) - that is a problem begging for a
> declarative solution.


Following your logic, shouldn't you rename testFoo() to ignoreFoo() then?

See where this leads?

--
Cédric
http://testng.org
